mn116:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Isigili Mountain.
mn116:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn116:4.1: “Mendicants, do you see that Mount Vebhāra?”
mn116:4.3: “It used to have a different label and description.
mn116:5.1: Do you see that Mount Paṇḍava?”
mn116:5.3: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:6.1: Do you see that Mount Vepulla?”
mn116:6.3: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:7.1: Do you see that Mount Vulture’s Peak?”
mn116:7.3: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:8.1: Do you see that Mount Isigili?”
mn116:8.3: It used to have exactly the same label and description.
mn116:9.1: Once upon a time, five hundred Buddhas awakened for themselves dwelt long on this Isigili.
mn116:9.2: They were seen entering the mountain, but after entering were seen no more.
mn116:9.3: When people noticed this they said:
mn116:9.5: That’s how it came to be labelled ‘Isigili’.
mn116:9.6: I shall declare the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves;
mn116:9.7: I shall extol the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves;
mn116:9.8: I shall teach the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves.
mn116:9.9: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
mn116:10.1: “The Buddhas awakened for themselves who dwelt long on this Isigili were named Ariṭṭha,
mn116:11.1: Those saintly beings, untroubled and free of hope,
mn116:11.2: who each achieved awakening by themselves;
mn116:11.4: the best of men, free of thorns.
mn116:13.3: awakened for themselves, enders of the attachment to being reborn.
mn116:14.1: Two sages named Jāli, and Aṭṭhaka,
mn116:14.2: Then the Buddha Kosala and Subāhu;
mn116:14.4: right and true, spotless and astute.
mn116:15.1: Kāḷa and Upakāḷa, Vijita and Jita,
mn116:15.2: Aṅga and Paṅga, and Guttijita too;
mn116:15.3: Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root,
mn116:16.3: Manomaya, and Bandhumant the cutter of conceit,
mn116:16.4: and Tadādhimutta the immaculate and resplendent.
mn116:18.2: another sage, Sayha of peerless effort.
mn116:18.3: There’s twelve Ānandas, Nandas, and Upanandas,
mn116:18.4: and Bhāradvāja, bearing his final body.
mn116:19.3: Tissa and Upatissa, who’ve both cut the bonds to rebirth,
mn116:19.4: Upasīdarin and Sīdarin, who’ve both cut off craving.
mn116:20.1: Maṅgala was awakened, free of greed,
mn116:20.2: Usabha cut the net, the root of suffering,
mn116:20.3: Upanīta who attained the state of peace,
mn116:21.3: Mānatthaddha, beautiful and free of greed,
mn116:21.4: and the Buddha Kaṇha, his mind well freed.
mn116:22.1: These and other mighty ones awakened for themselves,
mn116:22.2: enders of the attachment to being reborn—
mn116:22.3: honor these great seers who are finally extinguished,
mn116:22.4: having got past all ties, limitless.”
